data.title: Linde GAAP EPS of $4.21 beats by $0.37, revenue of $8.6B misses by $20M
data.description:
• Linde press release (LIN): Q3 GAAP EPS of $4.21 beats by $0.37.
  • Revenue of $8.6B (+2.4% Y/Y) misses by $20M.

  • For the fourth quarter of 2025, Linde expects adjusted diluted earnings per share in the range of $4.10 to $4.20, up 3% to 6% versus prior-year quarter or 1% to 4% when excluding 2% of estimated currency tailwind.

    For the full year 2025, the company expects adjusted diluted earnings per share to be in the range of $16.35 to $16.45, up 5% to 6% versus prior year with estimated currency to be flat. Full-year capital expenditures are expected to be in the range of $5.0 billion to $5.5 billion to support growth and maintenance requirements including the $7.1 billion contractual sale of gas project backlog.

data.title: Elon Musk’s SpaceX set to win $2B Pentagon satellite deal - report
data.description:
• Elon Musk's SpaceX (SPACE) is set to receive $2 billion to develop satellites that can track missiles and aircraft under President Donald Trump’s Golden Dome project, the Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.
  • The funding was included in the tax-and-spending bill that Trump signed in July, but wasn’t publicly linked to a contractor.
  • The planned “air moving target indicator” system could eventually field as many as 600 satellites, the report said.

data.title: NASA reviewing SpaceX, Blue Origin plans for faster return to the moon - report
data.description:
Elon Musk's SpaceX (SPACE) and Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin (BORGN) have submitted plans to NASA for ramping up efforts to take astronauts to the moon, the agency told CNBC.

NASA "has received and is evaluating plans from both SpaceX and Blue Origin for acceleration of HLS [Human Landing System] production," a spokesperson for the agency said. 

"Following the shutdown, the agency will issue an RFI to the broader aerospace industry for their proposals. A committee of NASA subject matter experts is being assembled to evaluate each proposal and determine the best path forward to win the second space race given the urgency of adversarial threats to peace and transparency on the moon," the spokesperson added.

SpaceX (SPACE) said it shared with NASA "a simplified mission architecture and concept of operations that we believe will result in a faster return to the moon while simultaneously improving crew safety."

Last week, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy told CNBC that SpaceX (SPACE) was behind schedule on building a lunar landing system for NASA's Artemis III manned mission.

"They push their timelines out, and we're in a race against China," Duffy said about SpaceX (SPACE). "The president and I want to get to the moon in this president's term, so I'm going to open up the contracts. I'm going to let other space companies compete with SpaceX, like Blue Origin."

"Blue Origin (BORGN) has never delivered a payload to orbit, let alone the Moon," Musk posted on X in response to Duffy's comments, later adding, "useful payload."

Duffy said NASA is targeting a crewed mission around the moon and back in early February, and get "back to the moon in 2028." China aims to send its astronauts to the moon by 2030.

data.title: Nomura expects Fed to keep rates unchanged in December meeting
data.description:
Nomura said it now expects the Federal Reserve to keep rates steady in its next meeting in December, after the Fed slashed interest rates on Wednesday.

The Fed reduced its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.75%-4.00% on Wednesday, its second straight cut, as it seeks to ease off the brakes in an effort to protect the labor market.

"Data are likely to be modestly dovish in the months ahead, but we doubt the weakness will be sufficient to rekindle FOMC concerns of a deteriorating labor market. We continue to expect three rate cuts in 2026," analysts led by Jeremy Schwartz said. 

Nomura's expectations come after Fed Chair Jerome Powell said a December rate cut is not a foregone conclusion. 

"A further reduction in the policy rate at the December rate is not a foregone conclusion. Far from it," Powell had said in his post-meeting press conference on Wednesday. 

Beyond just reclaiming optionality, Powell implied that a December pause was increasingly the default outcome, Schwartz said. 

Schwartz also called Powell's press conference "surprisingly hawkish" as the Fed Chair aggressively pushed back against market pricing for a December rate.

Traders were pricing in a 68.8% chance of another quarter-point rate cut in December, according to CME's FedWatch tool. 

More on the Federal Reserve

  • How Quantitative Tightening Helped Eliminate The Fed's Operating Losses
  • If The Fed Ends QT Too Soon, It Risks Discrediting Its Ceiling Tools
  • Why today's Fed cut could be one of the most stock-friendly ever

data.title: Portland General Electric reports mixed Q3 results; reaffirms FY outlook
data.description:
• Portland General Electric press release (POR): Q3 Non-GAAP EPS of $1.00 beats by $0.01.
  • Revenue of $952M (+2.5% Y/Y) misses by $31.83M.

  • 2025 Earnings Guidance

    PGE is reaffirming its estimate for full-year 2025 adjusted earnings guidance of $3.13 to $3.33 per diluted share (vs. $3.24 consensus) based on the following assumptions:

    • An increase in energy deliveries between 3.5% and 4.5%, weather adjusted;
    • Execution of power cost and financing plans;
    • Execution of operating cost controls;
    • Normal temperatures in its utility service territory;
    • Hydro conditions for the year that reflect current estimates;
    • Wind generation based on five years of historical levels or forecast studies when historical data is not available;
    • Normal thermal plant operations;
    • Operating and maintenance expense between $810 million and $830 million which includes approximately $135 million of wildfire, vegetation management, deferral amortization and other expenses that are offset in other income statement lines and $30 million of business transformation and optimization expenses;
    • Depreciation and amortization expense between $550 million and $575 million;
    • Effective tax rate of 15% to 20%;
    • Cash from operations of $950 to $1,050 million;
    • Capital expenditures of $1,220 million; and
    • Average construction work in progress balance of $575 million.

data.title: Ingram Micro outlines Q4 2025 sales guidance of $14B-$14.35B as Xvantage AI platform accelerates global growth
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Ingram Micro Holding Corporation (INGM) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Paul Bay highlighted that "the third quarter was strong with revenues of $12.6 billion, up 7.2% year-over-year and above the high end of our guidance. Non-GAAP diluted earnings per share was $0.72, at the high end of our guidance despite a small impact from the ransomware incident in July." He emphasized rapid recovery from the incident and pointed to market share gains and expanding momentum for the Xvantage digital platform, which is being deployed globally.

  • Bay stated, "Enterprise sales remained strong and our SMB customer category achieved a third straight quarter of sequential growth, which is encouraging." He noted that client and endpoint solutions delivered another solid quarter, while advanced solutions were down slightly year-over-year, but servers and storage posted strong double-digit gains. Networking growth was modest, driven by increased AI proof-of-concept activity.

  • The CEO discussed the company's multiyear plan to build an AI ecosystem, emphasizing investments in the Xvantage platform and the Enable AI program. He said, "In the third quarter, IDA contributed hundreds of millions of dollars of incremental revenue. We also had rapid international adoption of IDA with IDA-driven revenue with non-U.S. operations growing by more than 100% in the quarter."

  • Bay announced the launch of their first enterprise-grade AI agent, Sales Briefing Assistant, built with the Xvantage AI Factory and powered by Google's Gemini large language model, describing it as "a new standard for intelligence: scalable sales enablement in the enterprise."

  • CFO Michael Zilis stated, "We had a strong third quarter with results that either exceeded or hit the top end of each of our guidance ranges despite the impact of the July ransomware incident." Zilis detailed that the incident's total impact was within a tighter range of 1% to 1.5% of net sales and $0.02 to $0.03 per share.

Outlook

  • Zilis provided Q4 2025 guidance: "We are guiding net sales of $14 billion to $14.35 billion, which represents year-over-year growth of more than 6% at the midpoint. We expect fourth quarter gross profit of $935 million to $990 million, which would represent gross margins of roughly 6.8% at the midpoint. We expect non-GAAP diluted EPS to be in the range of $0.85 to $0.95 per diluted share."

  • The guidance reflects consistent trends in sales mix across products, customers, and geographies, with expectations of continued SMB strength and robust cloud growth.

Financial Results

  • Q3 net sales were $12.60 billion, up 7.2% year-over-year in U.S. dollars. Client and endpoint solutions grew nearly 13% on an FX-neutral basis. Advanced solutions sales declined by 4.5%, while cloud revenues dropped 4%, but excluding divestitures, cloud net revenues increased low single digits year-over-year.

  • Gross profit was $870 million compared to $845 million last year, and gross margins improved sequentially by 34 basis points. Operating expenses were $646 million, or 5.13% of net sales, with $5.5 million in divestiture-related losses and $3.5 million in restructuring costs.

  • Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter was $342 million. Non-GAAP net income rose 6% year-over-year to $169 million. Net working capital was $4.9 billion, and adjusted free cash flow was an outflow of $110 million, which Zilis noted was better than typical Q3 seasonal norms.

Q&A

  • Ruplu Bhattacharya, BofA Securities: Asked about margin trends and the impact of SMB versus large enterprise mix. Zilis answered, "what's implied in our guidance from a growth perspective is client and endpoint probably more in the mid-single digits... advanced solutions growing in the lower single digits and cloud growing mid- to upper single digits."

  • Bhattacharya followed up on inventory and free cash flow. Zilis responded, "we should see a solid cash flow quarter in Q4."

  • Maya Neuman, Morgan Stanley: Inquired about the hardware cycle for PCs and servers. Bay said, "we're in the back half or the later innings of the PC refresh. And if you look at server, that was a very good performance for us in the quarter within our advanced solutions."

  • Neuman also asked about pull-forward spend amid component cost inflation. Bay replied, "No, we haven't had any of those conversations at this point in time in terms of pull forwards or from a pricing perspective."

  • David Paige Papadogonas, RBC Capital Markets: Asked about Xvantage benefits. Bay explained, "Enterprise is using it for different reasons than SMB. SMB Is where they can really manage their whole business."

  • Papadogonas questioned AI-powered PCs extending the cycle. Bay said, "probably 25% of our PC shipments today, refresh, is an AI PC. So that's still a low percentage... we'll know more kind of at the beginning of next year."

  • Logan Katzman, Raymond James: Queried about a potential budget flush at year-end. Zilis said, "that is part of the reason we typically see a seasonal pop in revenues is budgeting cycles in Q4."

  • Alek Valero, Loop Capital: Asked about catalysts over the next 4 to 6 quarters. Bay highlighted, "it's around services that the partners are continuing to build out... it's around AI... and then security kind of wrapped around everything."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts focused on margin sustainability, hardware cycle timing, Xvantage's impact, and AI-driven opportunities, with a generally positive but probing tone.

  • Management maintained a confident tone, frequently reinforcing guidance and the positive impact of strategic initiatives, with Bay stating, "we are set up for a solid Q4."

  • Compared to the previous quarter, both management and analysts displayed increased confidence, especially regarding SMB growth and AI initiatives.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter saw a more confident outlook, with guidance for net sales and EPS higher than previous ranges. Management emphasized the AI ecosystem, the global scaling of Xvantage, and accelerating SMB growth as new highlights.

  • Analysts shifted focus from recovery post-ransomware in Q2 to structural growth drivers in Q3, particularly AI, Xvantage, and SMB momentum.

  • Management tone was more upbeat, referencing successful mitigation of the ransomware impact and the tangible benefits of strategic investments.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management discussed the July ransomware incident, quantifying its impact and highlighting rapid operational recovery.

  • Zilis noted that advanced solutions and cloud segments had some softness or mixed results, attributing some to noncore divestitures or project timing.

  • Analysts raised questions about margin mix, inventory management, and potential for pull-forward demand, with management offering clear responses and mitigation strategies.

Final Takeaway

Ingram Micro's Q3 2025 performance reflected strong revenue growth and robust execution in the face of disruption, supported by continued investment in digital and AI-driven platforms such as Xvantage. The company enters Q4 with upgraded guidance and high confidence, citing expanding SMB momentum, ongoing AI ecosystem development, and effective cost management as key drivers for future growth.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Magna International tops Q3 estimates; updates FY outlook
data.description:
• Magna International press release (MGA): Q3 Non-GAAP EPS of $1.33 beats by $0.08.
  • Revenue of $10.46B (+1.8% Y/Y) beats by $200M.
  • Adjusted EBIT increased 3% to $613 million, with a 10 basis-point improvement in Adjusted EBIT margin.
  • Increase 2025 outlook for Sales, Adjusted EBIT Margin, and Adjusted Net Income attributable to Magna, reflecting confidence in our strategic positioning and execution.
